newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo Jan M1 money supply falls 4.9 pct-Institute. [corrected 18:46 gmt]
newsitem.headline: Yugo Jan M1 money supply falls 4.9 pct-Institute. [corrected 18:46 gmt]

text.p: (Corrects month in headline from February to January).

Yugoslavia's M1 money supply fell 4.9 percent in January to 5.233 billion dinars ($929 million), the Institute for Market Research (IZIT) said on Monday in a report based on the central bank's latest figures.
This compared to 5.5 billion dinars at the end of 1996.
"Shrinking M1 was expected because it was necessary to halt the tumbling dinar from falling any further," IZIT's economist Slobodan Milosavljevic told Reuters.
A strong 10 percent monetary expansion late in December pushed the dinar down to as low as 4.3 to the German mark during eight days of New Year and Christmas holidays.
The dinar was changing hands at 3.9 to the mark ahead of the holidays.

Yugoslavia's government and the central bank vowed late last year to keep the dinar stable at 3.3 to the mark. It was fixed at 3.3 after a 70 percent devaluation in November 1995. Until then it had been fixed to the mark at par.
The share of cash in circulation fell to 2.523 billion dinars or 48.2 percent of M1 in January from 53.7 percent in December.
But deposits grew only 2.2 percent to 2.71 billion dinars in January, the report said.
The latest IZIT's survey showed M1 share in the country's gross domestic product (GDP) oscilated between five and eight percent in 1996.

Economists said M1-to-GDP ratio needed to grow further, but only gradually and to be accompanied with more financial rigour and an overall bank rehabilitation programme. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
